docs.snippet: Alejandro H. Berger of Cherry Hill, N.J., who was with the international division of Rohm  Haas, a Philadelphia plastics and chemical company, died Friday in the lunchtime bombing at Fraunces Tavern. He was 28 years old.

docs.snippet: CHICAGO, Feb. 7 American farmers who have been fattening cattle, hogs and poultry with corn and soybeans are now cutting back on their feeding operations more sharply than in any Period since the nineteen-fifties.
docs.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Feb. 7 American farmers who have been fattening cattle, hogs and poultry with corn and soybeans are now cutting back on their feeding operations more sharply than in any Period since the nineteen-fifties.
docs.abstract: another in series of articles assessing world food situation notes that Amer livestock producers are cutting back production due to econ reasons; points out that after '74 summer drought feed grain is at lowest point since World War II; states that costs of feeding livestock and poultry have soared above prices paid for animals on retail mkt; notes that by cutting back production, Amer farmers are hoping to force meat prices higher; points out that food forecasters are confident that meat supplies will increase when it becomes profitable again to raise and fatten livestock and poultry; notes that some optimistic observers believe that for rest of 20th century, if weather patterns are normal, animal protein supplies in affluent nations can be increased faster than population growth; these observers also believe that if underdeveloped nations can find means to acquire feed grains and create transportation systems for distributing meat, enough can be produced to increase animal protein in developing countries and improve people's diets; article holds that if assumptions are proven wrong, all food resources could be jeopardized; discusses world's livestock distribution, noting that N Amer, USSR, W Eur and parts of S Amer have largest concentration of meat consumption and livestock production; assesses whether livestock and poultry production can keep pace with world's population growth rate of 2% a yr and whether current high animal protein diets of more affluent countries can be continued in future without starvation in poor countries; studies conducted by Dr Leroy Quance, program leader of Agr Dept's Econ Research Service, by Natl Acad of Sciences, by Amer Forage and Grassland Council specialists W F Wedin, H J Hodgson and N L Jacobson, and by Agr Sciences and Tech Council cited; Animal Physiology and Genetics Inst chmn Dr James Smith comments; illus; charts show world meat production and avg per capita meat consumption in several countries (L)

headline.main: Hard Economics the Key to World Livestock Supply

byline.original: By SETH S. KING Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: NYC Council Pres Paul O'Dwyer, charging that city banks are exercising 'power of life and death over our munic insts,' urges that their lending practices be investigated by special Council com; refers to cancellation by Bankers Trust and Chase...
docs.abstract: NYC Council Pres Paul O'Dwyer, charging that city banks are exercising 'power of life and death over our munic insts,' urges that their lending practices be investigated by special Council com; refers to cancellation by Bankers Trust and Chase Manhattan Bank of their purchase of $260-million in city notes; also suggests that it be made possible for public to buy city notes directly from Controller's office and that these purchases be guaranteed by Fed Govt under agency resembling FDIC (S)

headline.main: Metropolitan Briefs; O'Dwyer Asks Inquiry on Banks
